_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



40 CFR 68.155(a) The Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies at the Stationary Source



The stationary source covered by this Risk Management Plan is the Terry Bundy Generating Station owned and operated by the Lincoln Electric System (LES).  LES is a municipally-owned and operated electric utility with sole service responsibility in and around Lincoln, Nebraska.  As a publicly owned utility, LES operates and maintains all of the equipment in our system in a manner representing prudent utility practices and in conformance with the expectations of LES customer/owner's.  LES strives for excellence in the facility operations and for full compliance with all local, state, and federal laws and regulations.



Meeting environmental requirements is part of LES policies and by developing and maintaining this Risk Management Program LES is complying with the Federal Accident Prevention Provisions (40 CFR Part 68) and the Risk Management Program defined in it.  LES is committed to the accidental release prevention program.  



LES maintains a thorough detailed Emergency Response Plan designated specifically for an ammonia release for the Terry Bundy Generating Station.  The plan will be reviewed with response organizations and others.  



40 CFR 68.155(b) The Stationary Source and Regulated Substance Handled



The LES Terry Bundy Generating Station, owned and operated by LES, provides emergency, peaking and base load electric power generation. The site is equipped with three landfill gas fired internal combustion generators rated at 2,242 brake horsepower (1600ekW) and three LM 6000 dual fuel aeroderivative combustion turbines located on the 320-acre site; one of which operates in simple cycle, and two operate in either simple cycle or combined cycle with a steam turbine.  The LM 6000 turbines are equipped with Selective Catalytic Reduction (SCR) for NOx emission control.  This system uses anhydrous ammonia which is fed into the

exhaust combustion gases upstream of the SCR catalyst modules.



Liquid anhydrous ammonia is stored in a pressure vessel under ambient temperature.  The pressure vessel has a 12,000 gallon or 60,000 pound capacity with a maximum fill level at 80%.  As the result, the normal operating amount of ammonia stored in the Terry Bundy Generating Station is 9,600 gallons or 48,223 pounds.  



40 CFR 68.155(c) The Worst-Case Release Scenario(s) and the Alternative Release Scenario(s), Including Administrative Controls and Mitigation Measures to Limit the Distances for Each Reported Scenario



Under the Risk Management Program, an offisite consequence analysis is required for an accidental release of a regulated substance.  In Terry Bundy Generating Station's case, anhydrous ammonia is the regulated substance.  Modeling of a worst-case release scenario and an alternative release scenario for anhydrous ammonia are required for offsite consequence analysis under Program 2.



EPA has defined a worst-case release as the release of the largest quantity of a regulated substance from a vessel that results in the greatest distance to a specified endpoint.  The largest quantity is determined by taking into account administrative controls that limit the quantity of a substance that can be stored or processed in a vessel at any one time, or alternatively, procedures that occasionally allow the vessel to store greater than usual quantities.   EPA defined alternative release scenarios to be any release that is more likely to occur than the worst-case scenario and that reaches an endpoint offsite.



For offsite consequence analysis, the movement and dispersion of a regulated aubstance release to the atmosphere is predicted using the computer model called Areal Locations of Hazardous Atmosphere (ALOHA).  ALOHA predicts pollutant concentration downwind from the source, taking into consideration the physical characteristics of ammonia, the physical characteristics of the site, weather con

dition, and the circumstance of the release.



The worst case scenario selected for the Terry Bundy Generating Station is the loss of 48,223 pounds of pressurized anhydrous ammonia representing a complete failure of the pressure vessel.  The entire content of the pressure vessel is released to the atmosphere within 10 minutes resulting in a release rate of 4,820 lbs/min.  Modeling results show that the worst-case scenario would have an offsite toxic endpoint of 1.0 miles.  The toxic endpoint is defined as the point where the ammonia concentration is below the level of concern, which is 0.14 mg/L or 200 ppm.



The alternative release scenario selected for the Terry Bundy Generating Station is the release of 48,223 pounds of pressurized anhydrous ammonia resulting from a failed connection on the pressure vessel.  The entire content of the pressure vessel is released to the atmosphere in 60 minutes resulting in a release rate of 804 lbs/min.  Modeling results show that the alternative release scenario would have an offsite toxic endpoint of 0.3 miles where the ammonia concentration drops below the level of concern of 0.14 mg/L or 200 ppm.

    

40 CFR 68.155(d) The General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps



Terry Bundy Generating Station has a Release Prevention Program in place to prevent accidental releases of hazardous materials at this facility.  The Release Prevention Program includes:



?    Safety Information (SI)

    LES develops and keeps current, working copies of SI documentation including information pertaining to hazards of the process, the technology of the process and the equipment of the process.  This information is used to inform employees and contractors.



?    Hazard Review (HR)

LES is committed to performing HR to identify, evaluate and control hazards associated with Terry Bundy Generating Station's operation and to comply with the requirements of 40 CFR 68.50.



?    Operating Procedures (OPs)

LES policy de

velops Terry Bundy Generating Station OPs as required and keeps them current.



?    Training

LES is committed to providing LES employees with comprehensive training to assure that the work force can perform their duties safely, efficiently and effectively.



?    Maintenance

LES has developed a written maintenance program for the ammonia system at Terry Bundy Generating Station.  The maintenance program includes pressure vessels and storage tanks, piping systems and ancillary equipment, relief and vent systems and devices, emergency shutdown systems, controls and pumps.  Maintenance procedures are developed or promulgated by equipment vendors, federal or state regulations, or industry codes.



?    Incident Investigation

The current Lincoln Electric System Emergency Ammonia Release Response Plan for Terry Bundy Generating Station is a component of the Incident Investigation process.  Incident reporting procedures are well defined.  Responsibilities, titles and phone numbers are given in a highly readable document.



40 CFR 668.155(e) The Five-Year Accident History



The five-year accident history involves an examination of the effects of any accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia in the five years prior to the submission of a Risk Management Program.  The five-year accident history would cover:



?    A release of anhydrous ammonia from Terry Bundy Generating Station that caused at least one of the following:

1.    Onsite deaths, injuries, or significant property damage (40 CFR part 68.42(a)); or

2.    Known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place (40 CFR part 68.42(a)).



The Terry Bundy Generating Station is a newly constructed facility, there have been no releases that conform with accidental release requirements that caused death, injuries, property damage, or environmental damage either on or off site.



40 CFR 68.155(f) The Emergency Response Program



LES has a thorough detailed Emergency Ammonia Rel

ease Response Plan designated specifically for an ammonia release for Terry Bundy Generating Station.  The plan is reviewed with response organizations and others.



40 CFR 68.155(g) Planned Changes to Improve Safety



LES will follow up on all of the recommendations of the Risk Management Program in a timely manner.  Any recommendations resulting from the revalidation of the Risk Management Program in the future will be dealt with in the same manner.
